incidents.title: 18 Arrested in ICE Raid at Nori Thai and Sushi Restaurant in Birmingham
incidents.summary: On November 14, 2025, ICE agents arrested 18 people at Nori Thai and Sushi in Birmingham's Altadena Square shopping center. The operation was described as an "arrest warrant operation centered around two aliens that had overstayed their visas." During the arrest of those two targets, 16 additional undocumented workers were encountered and arrested. The restaurant was not the primary target of the operation.
incidents.location: Altadena Square, Cahaba River Road at Acton Road

incidents.title: 82 Truck Drivers Detained in Statewide ICE-ALEA Enforcement Operations
incidents.summary: Between October 27 and November 18, 2025, the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency (ALEA) and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement detained 82 truck drivers during commercial motor vehicle inspections on Alabama's rural interstate corridors. The operations were conducted in two "Strike Force" phases targeting trucking industry workers. Governor Kay Ivey praised the partnership, while industry groups supported the crackdown on what they called "illegal operators."

incidents.title: 21 Detained in Russellville Checkpoint Raids Near Poultry Plant
incidents.summary: Federal and state agents apprehended 21 people in Franklin County during a Wednesday morning raid near the Pilgrim's Pride poultry plant. ICE, ATF, and Alabama Law Enforcement Agency officers set up roadblocks at shift-change times, checking immigration status at checkpoints on roads leading to major employers. Governor Kay Ivey praised the operation as a result of state-federal cooperation.
incidents.location: Franklin County Roads 144, 244, 75, 724 near Pilgrim's Pride

incidents.title: Lawsuit Filed Over ICE Courthouse Tactic: Dismiss Cases, Then Arrest Outside
incidents.summary: In August 2025, advocates filed a lawsuit on behalf of a dozen immigrants who were unexpectedly arrested after having their immigration court cases dismissed. A new ICE tactic had emerged where immigrants' cases were dismissed in immigration court with no reason given, and they were then arrested outside the courthouse. The practice created fear about attending court dates, as missing court results in in absentia removal orders.

incidents.title: HICA Volunteer and Youth Advocate Detained After Leeds Traffic Stop, Later Deported
incidents.summary: In early August 2025, Giovanna Hernandez Martinez, a volunteer for the Hispanic Interest Coalition of Alabama (HICA), was detained after a traffic stop in Leeds. Leeds Police contacted ICE and had her taken into custody. She was transferred to Pickens County Jail, then to ICE custody. A bilingual education advocate and social worker, she operated Juntos Coaching and Consulting, working with youth. After weeks in custody (reportedly lacking adequate healthcare access), Martinez was deported to Mexico - a country she hadn't been in since age 7.

incidents.title: 24 Arrested in Immigration Raids Across Mobile and Baldwin Counties
incidents.summary: On August 5-6, 2025, FBI Mobile confirmed immigration raids across Mobile and Baldwin Counties resulting in 24 arrests. Those arrested had prior convictions including forgery, assault, DUI, and immigration offenses. The operation represented continued enforcement pressure in the coastal Alabama region.

incidents.title: ICE Files Detainer on Honduran National Charged with Attempted Murder
incidents.summary: Javier Lopez Tinoco, a 20-year-old Honduran national, was charged with attempted murder for allegedly stabbing a victim three times during a public soccer game in Summerdale on July 19, 2025. He fled the scene but was arrested on July 29, 2025. At the time of arrest, he had 4 small bags of cocaine in his possession. ICE immediately filed an immigration detainer.

incidents.title: 11 Detained in ICE Raid at Loxley Elementary School Construction Site
incidents.summary: On July 23, 2025, agents with the Gulf of America Homeland Security Task Force conducted an immigration raid at the construction site of the new Loxley Elementary School in Baldwin County, Alabama. Eleven workers were detained. Eyewitnesses described workers fleeing across fields and climbing into attics to evade agents who arrived on four-wheelers with a helicopter overhead. This was the second immigration raid at a public school construction site in south Alabama in less than a month.
incidents.location: Loxley Elementary School construction site, County Road 64

incidents.title: 48 Detained in Coordinated ICE Raids on Mexican Restaurants Across Alabama
incidents.summary: On July 15, 2025, federal agents conducted simultaneous raids on eight Mexican restaurants across Alabama, detaining 48 people. While officials claimed the operation was part of a fraud investigation, only three people were placed in federal custody on criminal charges. Advocacy groups called the operation a "false flag" designed to meet deportation quotas, noting the massive resources deployed yielded minimal criminal evidence.
incidents.location: Multiple Mexican restaurants across East Alabama

incidents.title: 37 Detained in ICE Raid at Gulf Shores High School Construction Site
incidents.summary: Federal agents conducted an immigration raid at the new Gulf Shores High School construction site on June 24, 2025, detaining 37 workers. The $137 million taxpayer-funded facility was the first public construction project targeted by federal immigration enforcement in the area. FBI officials stated that 20 of those arrested had prior criminal histories, four had deportation orders, and seven had been previously deported.
incidents.location: Gulf Shores High School construction site, Foley Beach Express

incidents.title: ICE Arrests Iranian National with Military ID Card in Blount County
incidents.summary: On June 22, 2025, ICE Atlanta arrested Ribvar Karimi in Locust Fork, Blount County. Karimi reportedly served as an Iranian Army sniper from 2018-2021. At the time of arrest, he possessed an Islamic Republic of Iran Army identification card. He had entered the U.S. on a K-1 fiancee visa in October 2024 and married his American fiancee in January 2025 but never adjusted his immigration status. His arrest was part of a nationwide operation that detained 11 Iranian nationals that weekend.

incidents.title: 60 Arrested in Massive Multi-Agency Raid on Illegal Cockfighting Operation
incidents.summary: On June 14, 2025, the Gulf of America Homeland Security Task Force, USDA Office of Inspector General, and Alabama Law Enforcement Agency conducted a massive raid on an illegal cockfighting operation in Blount County. Six SWAT teams and two helicopters were deployed. The site housed over 250 birds bred for fighting. The investigation uncovered ties to gambling, drugs, tax evasion, firearms, and transnational criminal organizations.

incidents.title: Dozens Detained at Birmingham ISAP Check-In Appointments
incidents.summary: On June 5, 2025, ICE detained dozens of immigrants who arrived for routine check-in appointments at the Intensive Supervision Appearance Program (ISAP) office on Birmingham's Southside. Reports indicated approximately 50 people were detained in Birmingham and 18 in Gadsden. Many had been complying with immigration requirements for years. Advocates called the detentions a betrayal of trust, noting that those detained were "low-hanging fruit" who showed up believing they were following the law.

incidents.title: 28 Detained After Traffic Stop of Vans in Mobile County
incidents.summary: On June 3, 2025, Mobile County Sheriff's Office, alongside Homeland Security and FBI, conducted a traffic stop that resulted in the detention of 28 undocumented immigrants. The vans were pulled over for committing traffic violations. This represents one of the largest single-incident detentions in the Mobile area.

incidents.title: U.S. Citizen Detained Twice at Alabama Construction Sites, Files Federal Lawsuit
incidents.summary: Leonardo Garcia Venegas, a U.S. citizen born in Florida, was detained by ICE agents twice—on May 21 and June 12, 2025—during warrantless raids on private construction sites in Baldwin County, Alabama. Despite presenting his REAL ID both times, agents refused to release him immediately. He has filed a federal civil rights lawsuit challenging the raids as unconstitutional racial profiling.

incidents.title: Immigration Arrests in Southern Alabama Reach 500+ in 3.5 Months
incidents.summary: By May 16, 2025, federal law enforcement officials announced they had reached 500+ immigration-related arrests in southern Alabama over approximately 3.5 months (since late January 2025). The arrests included 9 accused members of a Venezuelan gang. The Southern District of Alabama encompasses 12 counties, with enforcement concentrated in the Mobile-Baldwin corridor.

incidents.title: 13 Arrested in Multi-Agency Criminal Enforcement Operation in Huntsville
incidents.summary: On March 25, 2025, ICE along with FBI, ATF, and DEA conducted an enhanced targeted enforcement operation in Huntsville focusing on individuals with criminal records. Eight of those arrested had been previously removed from the U.S. and had federal convictions for illegal reentry. Charges against those detained included domestic violence, narcotics trafficking, property crime, and DUI.

incidents.title: University of Alabama Doctoral Student Detained by ICE, Self-Deports After 45 Days
incidents.summary: Alireza Doroudi, an Iranian doctoral student in mechanical engineering at the University of Alabama, was detained by ICE at his home at 5 a.m. on March 25, 2025. DHS claimed he posed "significant national security concerns," but no evidence was ever presented to justify this claim. After 45 days in detention, Doroudi chose voluntary departure to Iran rather than face prolonged detention. His attorneys noted that DHS acknowledged during his hearing that the initial visa revocation charge was an error.

incidents.title: Construction Worker Spends Six Hours on Rooftop to Avoid ICE Arrest
incidents.summary: In late February or early March 2025, a construction worker in Spanish Fort became viral after spending six hours on a building's roof to avoid arrest by federal immigration officials. The standoff drew significant media attention and became a symbol of the fear gripping immigrant workers in Baldwin County's construction industry. The worker eventually came down from the roof but declined to comment when approached by media.

incidents.title: Multi-Agency Raids Target D.R. Horton Construction Sites Across Baldwin County
incidents.summary: From February 12-14, 2025, FBI, ATF, ICE, and Border Patrol conducted coordinated raids at multiple D.R. Horton housing developments across Baldwin County. More than 30 FBI agents participated in some raids. At the Jubilee Farms development in Daphne, a worker (Saul Cruz-Argueta) attempted to flee but was captured; he had been deported twice before. The raids marked a significant escalation of construction site enforcement in the region.

incidents.title: Notorious Etowah County Detention Center to Reopen for ICE Detainees
incidents.summary: In February 2025, Sheriff Jonathan Horton announced at the National Sheriffs' Association conference that the Etowah County Jail in Gadsden would resume detaining ICE detainees. The facility had closed its ICE contract in March 2022 amid documented abuse and deficiencies. With 865+ bed capacity, it was being prepared for renewed immigration detention. Negotiations had been ongoing since December 2024/January 2025.

incidents.title: ICE Raids Fultondale Home, Detains 3 Additional People Beyond Targets
incidents.summary: In late January 2025, ICE agents collaborated with Fultondale police to execute warrants at a residence during an early morning raid. Agents were looking for two specific individuals with outstanding reentry warrants. When they arrived at the house, they detained three additional people who were living in the home beyond their stated targets.
